I might guess you are getting a pin from Microsoft on your phone that you need to use. But without extensive knowledge of what security you have allowed and what privacy invasions you have permitted encouraged by Microsoft and their deceptive login dialogs there is no real way to guess what your operating system password/PIN is. content: First, to clarify: when you state that ...thunderbird\profiles is 32 gb, that includes all profiles. Do you have more than one profile in the folder? That's important, as it may be one that can be deleted, as thunderbird uses only one. Also, I see gmail.com and gmail-1.com, and googlemail.com. Is that three accounts? If not, then the gmail.com and gmail-1.com may be one account but duplicated. And, on your screenshot, you show a gmail.sbd, but not its contents, which may be more files.

content:
I can't access my password manager (Bitwarden).

Thunderbird and Bitwarden are completely independent from each other. So you can access your Bitwarden password manager any time you want, either via the browser extension or the desktop app.

Having said that, Thunderbird doesn't support passkeys, so use password login instead.
creator: christ1

content:
I was assuming that login window is my browser Firefox, just with all the features turned off. Are you saying it's actually Thunderbird's own thing, thus have no way to access my browser plugin?

Normally, to log in using passkey (not password), Google calls my browser plugin directly, a confirmation from Bitwarden shows up for me to click on. With Thunderbird's pop-up window, Google does not seem to be able to request passkey from Bitwarden. The login window does not show toolbar nor any of the browser plugin, and right click does not bring up context menu, so I can't access my password manager from there.

content: Hola, En una cuenta POP3 los correos están en el cliente de correo en decir en el Thunderbird, por lo tanto al eliminar la cuenta eliminara los correos almacenados en el Thunderbird, lo que puede hacer es copiarlos a la otra cuenta. Saludos
creator: pcp04

content:
just abut anything can be imported. But if it is worth it is the real question. An ICS file is a calendar file.

HTML is a web page, so sure you could probably convert it back into a calendar, but it would be a lot of work. Likewise CSV is the most basic data interchange format available really, being based on text. It might be useful if you were mail merging items in the calendar, but that is about the only practical use I can think of for it.

I would not consider any thing but ICS a good archival format for a calendar.
creator: MattAuSupport
